posts.name: Jixuxjixu
posts.cooked:
I have setup the machine using a monitor and keyboard and mouse( as standalone) and connected to my work wi-fi. And I have successfully connected it as a server using NVIDIA sync.

Then I have brought my DGX Spark home but I don’t have a monitor or keyboard. I was thinking I may use the Hotspot to setup it again because I need it to connect to my home wifi. But seems I cannot find any hotspot after I turn it up. ( Actually I don’t know whether it was turned up as no signal light on the machine LOL).

Anyone knows how can I deal with this situation? Staying online for answers.
The hotspot is only available during initial setup.

posts.name: Jixuxjixu
posts.cooked: So my only solution is buy a monitor if I want to use it at home? LOL

posts.name: Jixuxjixu
posts.cooked: Or is there a way to restore it to factory setup then I can re-setup it at home using the hotspot? @NVES
I’m checking with eng, but no obvious way to reimage a node that has not attached peripherals/headless and not on the network/wifi.

posts.name: Kberger
posts.cooked: I am not sure if this is what you are looking for. I tested this option this morning. At a simulated “work” I reimaged with a keyboard and monitor attached but no LAN connection. Once the reimage was done and I saw the “Press return to restart the system” I powered the device off by disconnecting the power cord. I then powered it on again at a simulated “home” with nothing attached. I can see the “spark” hotspot and was able to do the initial configuration. Please see if this might be an option that would work for your use case.

posts.name: Aniculescu
posts.cooked:
Not sure what your state is, but for others that want to do this, here are some steps you can follow.

  1. Connect Spark to router via Ethernet
  2. Try to connect with spark-hostname.local, if it works go to step 4
  3. View devices connected to router and find Spark (spark-hostname) IP
    a. Method may vary, you can use your router administrative panel or you may be able to connect directly to your spark by using the hostname if DNS works
  4. Connect to Spark via SSH or NV Sync app to open command line
  5. Use nmcli command to configure WiFi
    sudo nmcli d wifi connect <wifi_name> password <password>
  6. If connecting by hostname does not work, find IP address for WiFi interface
    ip -f inet a show wlP9s9
  7. Disconnect Spark from ethernet and use hostname or WiFi IP to connect

posts.name: Jixuxjixu
posts.cooked: This really helped. I could connect my Spark in my home wifi now without monitor and keyboard!

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 14 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
